div.head: Molding sulfur
div.ab: Sulfur is made beautiful mixed with soot black or pulverized bloodstone, which makes it harder and stronger. Having let it melt well until it becomes liquid, like oil, mix it with verdigris, and you m will cast in plaster very cleanly a lizard, or something else.

left-top You must not cast it until it is well cooled and has lost all of its lumps and bubbles, and it has settled down and become even like [illegible] water. The soot black gives it a fine luster and makes it neater. The most beautiful yellow sulfur must be used, for the greyish and lively sulfur is not good. Do not cast in wind and cold, for it would become porous.

Cimolee, otherwise known as fullerâ€™s earth, which prepares cloth, is excellent for molding hollow or in relief. And if you want to reheat it, it must first be warm, and reheat it gently on low, indirect flame, and little by little, otherwise it would crack. Put the figure for reheating in a pot in an oven, or in a covered oven. It is very malleable, clean and fine. You can make a hollow for animals of cimolee and cast lead in it.
left-middle The work needs to be dry for 4 or 5 days before you reheat it. When you mold and make a hollow in cimolee, do not press too hard, but gently, for it would crack.

The whitest and thinnest is the best. And when the hollow mold is quite clean, as when it is made of sulfur or baked cimolee, the paper comes out very clean. You can apply a layer or two of white, with a border of gold, to imitate alabaster. And after applying the white you may burnish it with a tooth. Yet in order for it to take burnish you should soak the lead white with egg white and peelings from the fig tree. Or better still, varnish your work with white varnish. Also while you are molding with paper, as it starts drying, burnish the back of it with the tooth.

Mountain plaster is greyer, and the the one from the region of Albi is whiter. It must be heated over a closed fire, such as a reverberatory furnace or fours de barbiers. And the best to work with is the most recently heated one. It must be finely ground on marble. After preparing your hollow mold with sulfur or something else, and oiling it, and investing with a circle, temper not too thickly your plaster with water, and stir it well with your finger, and if it makes lumps, throw in more powder of the said plaster and [illegible] grind it with your finger until +
left-bottom + it makes no more lumps. Then immediaty throw in and sprinkle plaster powder and leave to set well, then scrape the powder off.
